title: Don Quixote
author: Angel Brakus
description: Andr Bernard has researched the stories behind more than one hundred of the most famous titles in the English language to produce a fascinating volume rich in literary anecdote and publishing lore.

title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
author: Marguerite Rowe
description: Emily knocked the pile down and when she was picking it up discovered that one of the books was an old scrapbook. A loose leaf had fallen out of it. As Emily replaced it, her eyes fell on the description of a poem pasted on it.

title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
author: Alison Torp
description: This quotation for Faulkner’s 1936 novel comes from the Books of Samuel – more specifically, 19:4 in 2 Samuel, which is in the Old Testament and relates some of the history of Israel. Absalom, the third son of David, belled against his father and was killed in battle.

title: Wuthering Heights
author: Tracy Ward
description: This one is from 3:3 in the Ecclesiastes, again part of the Old Testament. The anonymous author is a King of Jerusalem who relates and analyses events in his own life. This has resonated strongly with a lot of people: Abraham Lincoln quoted Ecclesiastes when addressing Congress in 1862.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Beth Paucek
description: Another Ecclesiastes quotation, this time from line 7:4. A brilliant sentence: The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning; but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth. One of Wharton’s best-known novels, it came out in 1905.
